list_definition.definition: the solid part of the surface of the Earth which is covered by the sea

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: We had been at sea a week before we saw land.
He never made any money at farming as his land was poor and stony.

list_definition.definition: to come or bring down from the air upon the land

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The plane landed in a field
They managed to land the helicopter safely
She fell twenty feet, but landed without any serious injuries.

list_definition.definition: to come or bring from the sea on to the land

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: After being at sea for three months, they landed at Plymouth
He landed the big fish with some help.

list_definition.definition: to (cause to) get into a particular (usually unfortunate) situation

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He landed himself in trouble when he was caught speeding by a traffic cop.

list_ex_of_english: Before the heathland reclamations, the village areas consisted of small, closed villages with around them the fields (essen), the communal grazing lands and the forests.
Collective action can play a significant role in sustainable management of common grazing lands through restricting access and regulating use.
At the same time, in many accessible areas there are clear indications of agricultural expansion into unsustainable lands.
By using his access to capital, he began at an early age to secure an immediate interest in the lands of indebted landowners.
Several reasons can be adduced to explain this ' soft landing ' in the macro-economy.
At his death in 1500, he left his principal messuage and a workhouse to his elder son and other lands to a second son.
The fact that the rural poor have access to the most fragile lands induces significant environmental losses and soil degradation.
The mode of acquiring property rights in these lands varied considerably.
